item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
It‚Äôs spot-on! You‚Äôre right: cognitive warfare, supercharged by AI, aims to manipulate perceptions and curb critical thinking by overwhelming us with tailored information.

We agree psychological warfare isn‚Äôt new ‚ÄîU.S. pop culture, like movies, has shaped narratives for decades, casting some as heroes and others as villains.

Memes are a byproduct, subtly reinforcing ideas.

As the document notes, AI amplifies this, exploiting biases and big data. Education and awareness are key to resisting.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Dear Community, Based on @Uberbarbi ’s recent questions, we‚Äôve identified the need to update our documentation to clearly outline the components of the Babel Fish project.

We want to specify what‚Äôs currently in development, what‚Äôs in testing, and our long-term goals.

For website creation, we need detailed posts, courses, or tutorials to guide users on how to build sites now (e.g., using static sites and GitHub) and how the migration to our P2P network will work in the future.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Hello, @Uberbarbi . Let me clarify your doubts:

Our system is a P2P network where each node acts as a DNS server, resolving custom domains.

Currently, websites are hosted on platforms like GitHub and linked to our network.

You do need a computer to create your site now, but we‚Äôre working on an online tool for the future.

And no, your computer doesn‚Äôt need to stay on; once your site is synced to the network, it‚Äôs permanent.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Your ideas about why Salvador shares this with us are correct. The methodology of creating your second brain through note-taking is a practice for clarifying ideas. It can help you in different aspects of your life, not only in the technical or academic aspects, but also in introspection.

You can keep a journal, set life goals, and conduct self-analysis over defined periods of time.

Those who learn to keep organized records become highly effective people… By following the philosophy of digital gardens, you learn to filter the content you consume and form your own personal encyclopedia that you curate and maintain.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
https://obsidian.md/

You can use Obsidian to view and edit Markdown repositories… for example, when editing a static site.

Or for your personal notes.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Once we understand the power that the Markdown standard gives us, a door to a new world of possibilities will open before us.

The foundations of this new world are not new; they have been with us for decades, but what we do with it, my dear little birds, is what will change the world.

Study:

  • Zettelkasten, by Niklas Luhmann.
  • Personal Knowledge Management (PKM).
  • Second Brain.
  • Digital Gardens.

Once we master these concepts, we will add a P2P layer.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Markdown is the standard format par excellence for managing notes.

Notes? Yes, notes, like the ones you use to remember your study notes or your reminders.

But Salvador, we’re here to learn how to develop cutting-edge tools… why focus on simple notes???

The Markdown format allows you to store content and enrich it with simple tags. It doesn’t require compilers or sophisticated tools to edit or reproduce it. It’s like an HTML file, but with a much simpler syntax that is visually clear to the human eye. When it’s interpreted by a Markdown viewer, you can obtain the same results as with HTML, and you can also add JavaScript.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Study this…..

Introduction to Static Serverless Websites

Static serverless websites represent a modern trend in computing known as JAMstack (JavaScript, APIs, and Markup). This approach enables the creation of fast, secure, and scalable websites without the need to manage traditional servers.

Instead of relying on a server to generate dynamic content, static websites use pre-rendered files (HTML, CSS, and JavaScript) hosted on cloud services such as Netlify, Vercel, or GitHub Pages. These files are delivered to users via Content Delivery Networks (CDNs), simplifying infrastructure, reducing costs, and enhancing performance. The term JAMstack breaks down into:

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
The Storm is Coming. Trust the Plan.

teh_woman_in_red

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
üëÄ Will connecting chains help build bridges?

üëâ Yes, it can help build bridges between chains, but the main use case is that builders and users can have direct read and write access to any of the blockchains in the network.

üëÄ Boundless is addressing this fragmentation in chains.

üëâ Yes, but as we discussed previously, Boundless’s role is to provide zero-knowledge proof processing; it is a specific service for specific needs where high-confidence transaction verification is required.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Each user will be responsible for their own consumption.

But by being interconnected with everyone else through P2P, your node will also be supporting everyone else, and everyone else will be supporting you.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
üëÄ QL1 nodes, but also Bitcoin or other chains? So BabelFish isn’t a QL1 Layer 2? Why other chains other than QL1?

üëâ BabelFish will connect them all; creating a super mesh of chains.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
No, the hardware specification requirements should be minimal, as close as possible to the average user’s computer. It’s practically like an installed plugin.

This refers to the Babel Virtual Machine…

What will require additional processing is keeping nodes running. Remember that BabelFish will allow us to manage multiple nodes.

You can be running a QL1 node and also a Bitcoin node, and also a node for any other chain of your choice. And each will require its respective processing and storage space, but that will be the decision of each user.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
That’s right, Babelfish will be an additional layer over QL1. The most critical and permanent data will be recorded on the QL1 mainnet, and computational operations (processes) can be executed on Babelfish like an operating system.

Something like a Layer 2, focused on computing.

Thus, QL1 will remain optimal and cost-effective, as it won’t have to manage additional computational processes.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
We’ll eventually implement zero-knowledge proofs in our developments, which is why it will be useful to manage our own boundless node. But we need to carefully study the issue of operating costs.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Eventually, the Babelfish code will be published to become an open-source community project.

For now, it’s private for strategic reasons. Remember, there’s a risk that others will take Babelfish’s ideas and make them their own, like what happened with Vitalik a few weeks ago. That’s why we’ve decided to wait until the project is more mature to release the source code.

teh_woman_in_red

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
We focus on giving developers full control to develop any product their imagination and technical expertise allow.

We offer tools and guidance to beginners, but experienced developers can develop very quickly.

BabelFish itself is a distributed virtual machine that runs code and server functions. Think of Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Oracle… The entire internet is built on them, and now we’re there, but powered by QL1 the first CTO blockchain ever created.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Yes, it will have its own validators, but with different policies than QL1, as the network’s focus, purpose, and operations will be different. Details will be announced, but the system is designed so that everyone who contributes value to the network is rewarded accordingly.

item.description:
Dear Deep Thought Community, soar with us, kindred spirits! üïä

Across the vast sky of the digital realm, where free souls seek their truth, the BabelFish Protocol rises like a guiding star. We are a team dreaming of a world without digital chains, and you‚Äîweavers of code, testers of the breeze, and pioneers of this vision‚Äîare the wings of this revolution. Today, we share the map of our journey, a protocol that not only connects but sets us free. Come, fly with us into this new dawn.

As Babelfish development progresses, so will you as developers.

Babelfish is many things. In addition to being a node manager, it’s also a virtual machine for executing operations on the blockchain, a suite of utility applications for users, and a development framework for builders.

And you, who witness the project’s evolution, will also be the masters of the system.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Think of Babelfish as an engine. The software, by definition, is a general-purpose virtual machine, the Babel Virtual Machine.

Once the environment is set up and the main mechanisms are implemented, Babelfish will be a personal bridge between you (your devices) and the open sea of ‚Äã‚Äãthe on-chain internet.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Related to DNS, yes. The goal is to create a large, interconnected network of nodes that self-manage their own DNS resolution, not only to prevent attacks, but also to govern our own domain layer and, in turn, our own internet.

But that’s not the only goal of Babelfish; that’s just the DNS functionality.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
It seems you’ve found a key point.

Indeed, Babelfish doesn’t yet implement IPv6, so it will only work when the communication channel is through IPv4.

Babelfish starts its local DNS server and assigns it a local IP address and configures the computer’s network interface to use its own DNS server.

If DNS requests are made to our server, everything works fine; but if the system or browsers have more options (access to other DNS servers), they will try to use the others, primarily prioritizing the fastest one, in this case, IPv6, regardless of whether the DNS server is correctly resolving the domain name or not.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
just pc at this momeent (mac and windows), but mobile version will be available soon, also the linux and linux-server version will be ready on next days.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
And regarding the issue of censorship.

We are against any type of censorship. You are free to express, do, sell, or whatever you want on your site.

Remember, be good and don’t hurt others.

Individually, we don’t intend to censor; it goes against our values. But as an organized community, we are always looking for ways to make our ecosystem safe for everyone here.

But the scenario we want to avoid is truly extreme issues, something that truly puts the ecosystem or people at risk, not something as ambiguous as whether or not you sell things.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
It‚Äôs important to address this not only to you but to all members of the community:

As a development and research team, we focus on creating solutions and tools that improve people‚Äôs quality of life and uphold their right to browse and share freely.

Neither as individuals nor as a collective will we promote or support any activities that go against our community values.

Everyone is free to express themselves in their own corner of the internet‚Äîit‚Äôs their right.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
My friends, all of this is just in its infancy, and there are no tutorials or guides out there yet.

Here, as a community, it’s up to us to create these resources ourselves, and we all support each other with whatever knowledge we have so we can all grow.

At the moment, the devs are focusing on the protocol code, and the new members who are joining are starting to help us with testing from their computers. Some are writing guides; others are building their websites within our network.

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Leveraging BabelFish Protocol for Custom Domains

The BabelFish protocol allows you to connect custom domains to any location on the internet or blockchain.

The BabelFish dashboard offers tools for hosting and managing web content directly on the blockchain. However, it’s important to inform the community about the different hosting options available.

GitHub Pages is an excellent example of a free platform where you can host websites and easily connect them to a custom domain using the BabelFish protocol.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
• the IP can be fixed to any address you need.

  • the DNS server will be handled be BabelFish. It will be fixed:

    • When is ‘Connected’, the ip should be 127.3.6.9 (the qom numbers üòÜ), is the local DNS server inside BabelFish node.

    • When is ‘Disconnected’ is set 1.1.1.1, the public cloudflare DNS, in order to ensure user have regular dns resolution.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
That’s right, by owning a domain in the form of an NFT, anyone can develop products using their own domain names.

Of course, everyone must be careful about what data they make public, but the same applies to any project, whether it’s a legacy web project or a blockchain project.

teh_woman_in_red

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
The core functionality of BabelFish is already up and running.

Now it’s up to each small developer to create their sites and invite others to join.

The BabelFish software will continue to be updated, and once the testing phase is complete, domains will be minted as NFTs and can be managed directly on the platform.

teh_woman_in_red

Related articles

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
‚ÑπÔ∏è Important reminder (connect / disconnect):

Babelfish enables communication with a QL1 node through a local server on the user’s device, and for this it makes a couple of configurations in the system preferences.

  • When starting the app, the server starts.

  • When you activate the ‘Connect’ button, the configurations are made in the network preferences.

  • When you disconnect, network configurations are restored.

üõü As we are in a test phase, we have added a block to close the app:

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
You might want to click the ‘Sync’ button on your dashboard, just in case the node hasn’t performed its automatic sync yet.

Every so often, the node checks for changes; usually, every 5 minutes. The Sync button is there to force the check, so you don’t have to wait for the automatic update to see any changes.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
Yes, one of the goals is to give users the ability to store part or all of their sites on different decentralized networks and protocols; as well as decide where they want that content to be accessible, whether on the common internet, only on the Babelfish network, or both.

And with the assurance that everything built and hosted on our protocol will be resistant to censorship or arbitrary disconnection.

item.author: e@mail.qom (Jane Doe)
item.description:
As the project progresses, it will be necessary to manage test environments for specific features. To achieve this, the installable Babelfish software must support multiple chains and direct peer-to-peer communication between nodes.

A minimum of two Babelfish nodes pointing to the same chain (mainet or testnet) will be able to interact.
